boat.construction_details: Carvel pitch pine on grown oak frames
boat.full_description:
There is some question over Venture's build date, quoted as 1920-25 or 1890-1910.

Venture was salvaged in 1965 by Dennis Crompton of Warrington who gave her a major overhaul. He sold her to Jay Cresswell (OGA member) in 1974, who re-registerd her for commercial fishing on the Beaumaris register (BS 120). Widely regarded in the nobby community as being a Fleetwood-build around 1920 because of her powerful bows and hefty build (for a nobby). She was an Irish Sea boat rather than nearshore model.

Sold south in 1977 after three successful years of work, mostly in Scottish waters. New owner was Sam Bayliss (also OGA member). He attempted to buy her back in the early 1980s through a proxy but failed. She had a major refit 1996-9, and was for sale in 2004 - 2006

It is possible that she was originally called 'Lizzie' though the name Venture reaches way back according to Nobby man, the late Ronnie Baines of Fiddler's Ferry, later Deganwy. His view was that she was originally a Fleetwood boat. Curiously, he too had owned a nobby called Venture, but a different boat. There has been another Venture afloat and which fished the Morecambe Bay area. A grp hull modelled off the Sir William Priestley.

The registration CO88 is a 'red herring'. The fishing Nobby CO88 was bought during the war by a company taking advantage of subsidies paid to the fishing industry. She was abandoned at the end of the war in the Manchester Ship Canal. Venture recycled her sail. It was used as the pattern for a new main, which was ordered from Fleetwood Trawler Supply Co. which still had a loft at that time. It was a powerful yet manageable sail and enabled Venture to tow a beam trawl comfortably.

The foresail had been made many years earlier, again for another nobby, but was like new. The jib was made by Leitch of Tarbert using an earlier sail as the pattern/
boat.name: Venture
boat.short_description: She was originally a fishing Nobby in North west England.
